awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Provable Quantum Advantage – Present and Future
awd_abstract_narration:
For nearly three decades quantum computation has been the only known model of feasible computation capable of obtaining exponential speedups over any efficient classical computer [11,29,30]. Despite this great promise, the theoretical quantum speedups developed in the early 1990’s are very difficult to implement as they require large-scale, nearly perfect quantum experiments. While this goal may still be quite far off, the push to develop quantum computers has already yielded incredible experimental progress in high-precision control over individual quantum systems across many different quantum architectures (see e.g.,[7,10,12,34,35]). Due to these experimental developments, we have now arrived in the so-called Noisy Intermediate Scale Quantum (“NISQ”) era, in which quantum systems of 50-70 qubits are currently being built in experimental laboratories around the world. For the first time, these experiments are approaching the complexity boundary after which it is unclear how to simulate them classically in a reasonable amount of time. This indicates that these systems may have the potential to achieve quantum speedups. However, these experiments have important limitations, such as uncorrected noise, which restrict their capabilities. The first major step for the NISQ era is to implement an experimental demonstration of a computational speedup relative to any classical computer, a goal known as “quantum supremacy” [27]. This goal is a watershed moment in the history of computation and a necessary milestone on the path toward developing fully scalable quantum computers. Moreover the goal appears to be rapidly approaching, and we have already seen the first claimed demonstrations of quantum supremacy [7, 36]. These experiments have attracted much attention but there are still many aspects of the claims that not well understood. While there is some rigorous evidence that such near-term quantum experiments are able to attain exponential speedups over classical computation (see, e.g., [3,4,14]) these theoretical results do not take into account many practical facets of these experiments such as uncorrected noise. Indeed, these gaps between theory and experiment have resulted in partial rebuttals of these initial quantum supremacy claims (see e.g., [8, 22, 25, 26]). Consequently, there is a great need to rigorously understand the capabilities of these near-term quantum experiments. To do this, we propose holding a workshop focusing on the prospects for achieving large computational speedups on near-term quantum experiments. Our goal will be not only be to better understand the present generation of quantum experiments, but also to understand the capabilities of tomorrow’s quantum experiments, with a view toward the ultimate goal of implementing a quantum speedup for solving a practically useful problem. Intellectual Merit:The proposed workshop will lead to a complete understanding of the computational power of near-term quantum experiments. The focus will be on three objectives which will together help understand the power of existing quantum computers, as well as pave the road toward understanding the power of future quantum devices capable of attaining dramatic speedups for useful computational problems. In addition to being critical for the current near-term quantum era, these aims will foster interdisciplinary collaborations and lead to exciting new insights at the intersection of computer science, engineering, and experimental physics. Broader Impacts:This workshop will contribute to sustaining and enhancing the recent worldwide explosion of interest in quantum computation. The program will feature invited speakers and participants from academia, government and industry to disseminate the most recent ideas on quantum computation to a wide variety of scientific communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For nearly three decades quantum computing has been the only known model of feasible computation capable of obtaining exponential speedups over any efficient classical computer. Despite this promise, the theoretical quantum speedups developed in the 1990's are difficult to implement as they require large-scale, perfect quantum experiments.  While this goal may still be far off, the push to develop quantum computers has already yielded incredible experimental progress in high-precision control over individual quantum systems across many different quantum architectures.  Due to these developments, we have now arrived in the so-called Noisy Intermediate Scale Quantum (``NISQ'') era, in which quantum systems of 50-70 qubits are being built in experimental laboratories around the world.  

The first major step for the NISQ era, and the focus of this NSF workshop, is to implement an experimental demonstration of a computational speedup relative to any efficient classical computer, a goal known as “quantum advantage”.  This goal is a watershed moment in the history of computation and a necessary milestone on the path toward developing fully scalable, fault-tolerant quantum computers.  Moreover the goal appears to be rapidly approaching, and we have already seen the first claimed demonstrations of quantum supremacy.  These experiments have attracted much attention but there are still many aspects of the claims that not well understood.  

The NSF workshop began with keynote talks given by Umesh Vazirani and Scott Aaronson, both noted pioneers in the field of quantum computation.  These talks gave a summary of the status quo of the field, providing a description of the current generation of quantum advantage demonstrations, as well identifying potential “loopholes”, or areas in which these experiments could be improved to give more compelling evidence of a quantum speedup.  Both Vazirani and Aaronson described the need for new examples of problems which are implementable by near-term experiments, have rigorous proofs of classical hardness and yet have solutions that can be verified efficiently by classical algorithms.  Currently, every known proposal for quantum advantage has at most two of these properties.  This message echoed throughout the rest of the workshop, which focused on three interrelated topics concerning current quantum advantage experiment.

The first topic is to understand a variety of near-term quantum experiments and to give rigorous justifications that these experiments are capable of solving problems that cannot be solved in a comparable amount of computation time on a classical computer.  Talks at the workshop featured a number of different experimental proposals, including the BosonSampling proposal for quantum advantage with linear optical experiments, and the Random Circuit Sampling proposal for quantum advantage using a superconducting qubit architecture.

The second topic of the NSF workshop concerned methodology for using a classical computer to verify quantum advantage demonstrations.  This verification task is extremely important since near-term quantum experiments are very noisy, due to the phenomenon of decoherence, or unwanted interactions with the external environment.  Several talks at the workshop focused on the “linear cross-entropy” method for benchmarking near-term quantum experiments and on classical algorithms for spoofing this method.

The third topic of the NSF workshop concerned channeling the power of quantum advantage experiments to solve useful problems, rather than only serving as “proof of principle” demonstrations that quantum computers can outpace classical supercomputers.  In the last few years a number of useful candidate problems have been proposed to take advantage of modern quantum advantage experiments.  For example, while Google’s random quantum circuit sampling experiment was not originally intended to solve a useful problem, recent work due to Aaronson has given evidence that these experiments could be useful for the generation of certifiable random numbers, with important cryptographic applications.  Furthermore, claims have been made that BosonSampling experiments can solve useful applications to quantum chemistry such as the “molecular vibronic spectra” problem.  Talks at the workshop focused on these potential applications, as well as to finding classical algorithms to potentially “dequantize” aspects of these applications.

In conclusion, the NSF workshop investigated a wide range of topics relevant to the pursuit of near-term quantum computational advantage.  Workshop participants proposed several critical directions for future research including:

  1. Can we find efficient classical methods for the verification of random quantum circuit sampling or BosonSampling experiments?
  2. Can we use the benchmarking tests developed to verify quantum advantage experiments to verify important properties of other near-term quantum experiments, such as analog quantum simulation experiments?
  3. Can the power of near-term quantum advantage demonstrations be channeled to solve useful problems, either pertaining to cryptography (e.g., certified random number generation) or to computational problems in physics and chemistry (e.g., to spectroscopy or quantum simulation problems?)
  4. Current quantum advantage experiments will not readily scale to larger system sizes due both to uncorrected noise and to lack of efficient verification protocols.  What is the minimal amount of quantum resources (circuit depth etc.) needed to implement a fully scalable demonstration of quantum advantage?
